Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learn python for data science, principles of statistics and machine learning, and how to implement them.
This course taught me valuable coding skills, and it introduced me to a number of data science tools.

In this course, I gained experience with python and even TensorFlow. I also familiarized myself better with Data Analysis techniques that I had seen before but had never implemented before such as PCA, k-means, gradient descent etc. I definitely learned how to implement practical data science methods, though given my math background I probably could have taught myself these methods without taking the course.
I attended selected lectures as I was auditing the class, and the course seamlessly mixed between theory and practice

This course gives a brief overview of some simple and some complex statistical modeling skills. While the lectures do not delve into much detail, you learn python and its related packages to build different statistical models. The lectures do not cover much on the coding, and you are left to your own devices to learn the necessary skills when doing the homework.
Learnt to use python for data analysis and statistical modelling
I actually learned a good amount. I'm a math major and have never really done data science stuff before, so I learned how to work in python and do real things with real data sets

Gradient descent
Principal components
Numpys, Pandas,Tensorflow
Spark
Learned the fundamentals of statistical analysis using python.
A better understanding of how to use Python data science libraries and the mathematics underlying popular data science techniques.
I learned about Python and algorithms like PCA and Neural Nets.
I learned so much on how to use to Python and different methods of optimization for data science.
An understanding of various computational methods in data science
Course was ok, a good opportunity to use Python. Lectures were often pretty unclear however.

This course introduced me to a number of complicated learning methods and taught me how to learn new coding tools.  However, a major weakness was un-connected nature of our course.  There were a number of tools I learned but did not understand how to apply to the real world or why I would select it.  Additionally, the lack of a textbook was a major weakness. I loved what I learned but I'm not sure how to apply it to the real world.

The lectures are really clear, easy to understand and go at a nice pace. The course assignment schedule was a bit disorganized and unclear. The grading policy was also a bit unclear. The assignments themselves were clear and also fun. They were challenging but doable.

The strengths are that it covers a lot of interesting material. The weaknesses are that it seems like the topics are not tied together well. Furthermore, I would have liked to have covered less topics but in more depth. The days when Sahand presented real world examples were fascinating lectures but at times it seemed as if he and the class were lost in theoretical details. I left the class feeling like I didn't learn a lot because we just brushed over so many advanced topics.

Some assigned readings may have helped to understand the significance of the class and its topics as well as help understand the material more.

Lectures weren't very engaging, but problem sets were interesting to think about and complete. I enjoyed the guided process of having an ipython notebook with text that guides you along in completing the assignment.

Strengths: I definitely learned some stuff from this class, mostly from working on the psets. 

Weaknesses: Lectures weren't the easiest to follow. No lecture notes were posted online and there was no textbook so it was hard to find places to read over the material. Office hours were often last minute cancelled or rescheduled. Psets often took a very long time to be graded.

Don't know whether this is a strength or a weakness, but there are no tests. Your entire grade is made up of 5 psets at 20% each. Something to be aware of.

Instructors are great!


Syllabus is not clear
Assignment grading is not clear
Reference material is not provided.

The course teaches very interesting and engaging topics. 

Sometimes the homework was unclear and the directions were confusing.
Covered a broad range of topics; problem sets were a bit disorganized at times
The Psets are well structured and the material is pretty important for those who want to learn data science.
Most of the class was taught on the blackboard while all the homework was coded in Python.  I wish we learned how to code more in class.
It's very disorganized and the material was not presented clearly.

This class was very disorganized. We were only assigned 6 of the 7 planned homeworks, presumably because we did not stay on course with the lecture schedule. This made it difficult to plan the rest of the semester because the dates for the assignments were not set. In addition, I found that I learned best by implementing the methods learned in the homeworks, so I would have liked an extra chance to practice a topic.

Sure. Python is a good skill to have in data science and the machine learning concepts we cover (PCA, neural networks, etc..) are important. However, lectures are pretty unclear so it is sometimes hard to learn the material.

No i do not, this is one of the worst classes i have taken at Yale. As an S&DS major there are plenty of other classes to get an elective out of. This class is poorly taught which is a shame because the material in this class is super awesome, useful, and interesting.

This is a super cool course that will teach very valuable skills.  However, unless you have a coding and math background, this course will be very very very difficult.  Also, I would recommend buying a related textbook on Amazon to help out.

This course was certainly well taught, but I came in with too advanced a background to get much out of the class. I ended up skipping 75% of the lectures and finding the problem sets quite easy. Therefore if you are senior or junior who has done a bunch of math, computer science and statistics this class will be too easy (but sometimes it is nice to have an easier class :) ). If you are a first year or sophomore, or if you are an upperclassman without much exposure to data science, math or statistics this class would be a better fit for you.
Yes

Probably not. I took the class because I thought it would give me a good preview of some stat classes I could take in the future. Instead, I left the course feeling like I didn't learn a lot because we didn't go into a lot of depth on any topic. Sahand is an incredibly smart professor who is good at lecturing but his lessons are very dense and are hard to internalize immediately. Since there are not additional materials or assigned reading, you are left on your own to figure out a lot of topics. With that being said, you do learn how to code in python and get a general idea of some advanced statistical techniques while doing the p sets, but most of the learning comes from your own work.

A good way to get an introduction to using Python for data analysis and statistical modeling. Also provides good exposure to some common machine learning methods and concepts, all with a very manageable workload and little stress (since there aren't any tests or exams).
Eh maybe. I'm actually glad I took it as I think I learned from it. However, it was not the most interesting course ever and not very well organized.
I would recommend this class if you want a general overview on topics such as regression/PCA/Spark.

DO NOT RECOMMEND WITH SAHAND. Sahand puts together terrible "lecture" notes, which are basically either half-baked Python scripts that he corrects on the fly and never has time to post ahead of time, OR him writing math on the board in a way that seems almost intentionally disorganized, which he erases and corrects every three minutes. Don't take notes with a pen. And make sure your notebook paper has ample margins, because as he modifies his board scrawl, which he will, and using whatever board room he has, you will need to add things in random margins and use arrows, etc. 2/10 would recommend.
Pretty relaxed course with a rigid structure, introduces some interesting topics and teaches you some important Python skills for data science
The course could use some more structuring and better planning in terms of what material is covered each week, but it is still interesting.
The course was tough, but extremely interesting.  I highly recommend if you are interested in data analysis.

i took it cr/d which i would recommend because even though the class is only psets and no exams, no final, the material to me was pretty tough. never coded in python before and found the psets really hard to figure/do on my own. had to utilize google a lot
I would not recommend this course to another student as I feel that I didn't get too much out of it other than learning python.

Do not take this class with Sahand. The class was very disorganized and you have to learn many of the topics on your own to implement in the homeworks. On the plus side, you get valuable experience using Python, there are no exams, and the homeworks are very manageable and usually quite interesting.
